heading_context: Disciplinary procedures and action against you at work
chunks.html_content:
Your employer could start formal disciplinary action against you if they have concerns about your work, conduct or absence.

Before taking formal disciplinary action or dismissing you, your employer may try to raise the matter informally with you. However, they can go straight to their formal disciplinary or dismissal procedures.

Disciplinary procedures are a set way for an employer to deal with disciplinary issues. They should include a disciplinary hearing where you’re given a chance to explain your side of the story.

There should also be a chance to appeal any disciplinary action your employer decides to take.
chunks.plain_content:
Disciplinary procedures and action against you at work
Your employer could start formal disciplinary action against you if they have concerns about your work, conduct or absence.
Before taking formal disciplinary action or dismissing you, your employer may try to raise the matter informally with you. However, they can go straight to their formal disciplinary or dismissal procedures.
Disciplinary procedures are a set way for an employer to deal with disciplinary issues. They should include a disciplinary hearing where you’re given a chance to explain your side of the story.
There should also be a chance to appeal any disciplinary action your employer decides to take.

heading_context: Disciplinary procedures and action against you at work
Disciplinary steps
chunks.html_content:
Your employer should put their disciplinary procedure in writing, and make it easily available to all staff.

It should say what performance and behaviour might lead to disciplinary action and what action your employer might take.

It should also include the name of someone you can speak to if you do not agree with your employer’s disciplinary decision.

Your employer’s disciplinary procedure should include the following steps:

  1. A letter setting out the issue.

  2. A meeting to discuss the issue.

  3. A disciplinary decision.

  4. A chance to appeal this decision.
chunks.plain_content:
Disciplinary procedures and action against you at work
Disciplinary steps
Your employer should put their disciplinary procedure in writing, and make it easily available to all staff.
It should say what performance and behaviour might lead to disciplinary action and what action your employer might take.
It should also include the name of someone you can speak to if you do not agree with your employer’s disciplinary decision.
Your employer’s disciplinary procedure should include the following steps:


A letter setting out the issue.


A meeting to discuss the issue.


A disciplinary decision.


A chance to appeal this decision.

heading_context: Disciplinary procedures and action against you at work
Acas (Advisory, Conciliation and Arbitration Service) Code of Practice
chunks.html_content: Your employer’s disciplinary procedures should follow the Acas Code of Practice on disciplinary and grievance procedures.
chunks.plain_content:
Disciplinary procedures and action against you at work

Acas (Advisory, Conciliation and Arbitration Service) Code of Practice
Your employer’s disciplinary procedures should follow the Acas Code of Practice on disciplinary and grievance procedures.

heading_context: Disciplinary procedures and action against you at work
Acas (Advisory, Conciliation and Arbitration Service) Code of Practice
chunks.html_content: Your employer does not have to follow the Acas code. However, if they do not and you win an employment tribunal against them, you could get a larger payout.
chunks.plain_content:
Disciplinary procedures and action against you at work

Acas (Advisory, Conciliation and Arbitration Service) Code of Practice
Your employer does not have to follow the Acas code. However, if they do not and you win an employment tribunal against them, you could get a larger payout.

Acas (Advisory, Conciliation and Arbitration Service) Code of Practice
chunks.html_content: There’s more guidance about how employers should run disciplinaries in the Acas guide on discipline and grievances at work.

heading_context: Disciplinary procedures and action against you at work
Disciplinary procedures and employment contracts
chunks.html_content: Your employer can also put their disciplinary procedures in your employment contract.
chunks.plain_content:
Disciplinary procedures and action against you at work
Disciplinary procedures and employment contracts
Your employer can also put their disciplinary procedures in your employment contract.

heading_context: Disciplinary procedures and action against you at work
Disciplinary procedures and employment contracts
chunks.html_content: If your employer does this and then does not follow these procedures you could sue them for breach of contract.
chunks.plain_content:
Disciplinary procedures and action against you at work
Disciplinary procedures and employment contracts
If your employer does this and then does not follow these procedures you could sue them for breach of contract.

heading_context: Disciplinary procedures and action against you at work
Northern Ireland
chunks.html_content: Northern Ireland has different ways of solving workplace disputes.
chunks.plain_content:
Disciplinary procedures and action against you at work
Northern Ireland
Northern Ireland has different ways of solving workplace disputes.

heading_context: Disciplinary procedures and action against you at work
Taking someone with you to a disciplinary hearing
chunks.html_content:
Your employer should not take any disciplinary action before meeting with you first and discussing the problem.

This disciplinary meeting (normally called a ‘hearing’) should be at a reasonable time and place.

At the hearing your employer should:

  • explain the complaint against you
  • go through the evidence
  • give you a chance to tell your side of the story

If you raise a significant new fact or issue at the hearing your employer might stop it and look into the issue. They should then rearrange the hearing at a later date.
chunks.plain_content:
Disciplinary procedures and action against you at work
Taking someone with you to a disciplinary hearing
Your employer should not take any disciplinary action before meeting with you first and discussing the problem.
This disciplinary meeting (normally called a ‘hearing’) should be at a reasonable time and place.
At the hearing your employer should:

  explain the complaint against you
  go through the evidence
  give you a chance to tell your side of the story

If you raise a significant new fact or issue at the hearing your employer might stop it and look into the issue. They should then rearrange the hearing at a later date.

heading_context: Disciplinary procedures and action against you at work
Taking someone with you to a disciplinary hearing
chunks.html_content: You have the right to take someone with you to a disciplinary hearing, but you must tell your employer about this first.
chunks.plain_content:
Disciplinary procedures and action against you at work
Taking someone with you to a disciplinary hearing
You have the right to take someone with you to a disciplinary hearing, but you must tell your employer about this first.

heading_context: Disciplinary procedures and action against you at work
Taking someone with you to a disciplinary hearing
chunks.html_content:
Your companion can be either:

  • a colleague
  • a trade union representative
  • a trade union official

If a colleague cannot go with you and you’re not in the union you can ask to bring a family member or a Citizens Advice worker. However, your employer does not have to agree to this unless your employment contract says they must.

The companion can:

  • present and/or sum up your case and say things to support your case
  • speak to you during the hearing
chunks.plain_content:
Disciplinary procedures and action against you at work
Taking someone with you to a disciplinary hearing
Your companion can be either:

  a colleague
  a trade union representative
  a trade union official

If a colleague cannot go with you and you’re not in the union you can ask to bring a family member or a Citizens Advice worker. However, your employer does not have to agree to this unless your employment contract says they must.
The companion can:

  present and/or sum up your case and say things to support your case
  speak to you during the hearing

heading_context: Disciplinary procedures and action against you at work
Taking someone with you to a disciplinary hearing
chunks.html_content: Your companion cannot answer questions on your behalf.
chunks.plain_content:
Disciplinary procedures and action against you at work
Taking someone with you to a disciplinary hearing
Your companion cannot answer questions on your behalf.

heading_context: Disciplinary procedures and action against you at work
Disciplinary action
Taking someone with you to a disciplinary hearing
chunks.html_content:
Your companion cannot be disciplined for supporting you.

After the hearing your employer should write to you as soon as possible, saying what action they’re going to take, and telling you about your right to appeal.

The decision might be:

  • no action
  • written warning
  • final warning
  • demotion
  • dismissal

It might also be anything else that could resolve the problem, for example an agreement to mediate with a co-worker you’ve had personal problems with.
chunks.plain_content:
Disciplinary procedures and action against you at work
Disciplinary action
Taking someone with you to a disciplinary hearing
Your companion cannot be disciplined for supporting you.
After the hearing your employer should write to you as soon as possible, saying what action they’re going to take, and telling you about your right to appeal.
The decision might be:

  no action
  written warning
  final warning
  demotion
  dismissal

It might also be anything else that could resolve the problem, for example an agreement to mediate with a co-worker you’ve had personal problems with.

heading_context: Disciplinary procedures and action against you at work
Appeal hearings
chunks.html_content:
If you think disciplinary action taken against you is unfair you can appeal.

Write to your employer saying you’re appealing and why.

You should be offered another meeting to discuss your appeal. This appeal hearing should be held as soon as possible.

If possible it should be dealt with by someone who has not already been involved with your disciplinary action.

An appeal hearing will be similar to your original disciplinary meeting and you’ll have the right to bring a companion.
chunks.plain_content:
Disciplinary procedures and action against you at work
Appeal hearings
If you think disciplinary action taken against you is unfair you can appeal.
Write to your employer saying you’re appealing and why.
You should be offered another meeting to discuss your appeal. This appeal hearing should be held as soon as possible.
If possible it should be dealt with by someone who has not already been involved with your disciplinary action.
An appeal hearing will be similar to your original disciplinary meeting and you’ll have the right to bring a companion.

heading_context: Disciplinary procedures and action against you at work
Final decision
chunks.html_content: After the appeal meeting your employer should write to you with their final decision.
chunks.plain_content:
Disciplinary procedures and action against you at work
Final decision
After the appeal meeting your employer should write to you with their final decision.

heading_context: Disciplinary procedures and action against you at work
Employment contracts
chunks.html_content:
When a disciplinary issue is being looked into you might be suspended from work. This does not happen very often. If it does it should normally be with pay and you should be told why you’re being suspended.

You can be suspended without pay if your employment contract says your employer can do this, but they must be acting reasonably.

If your employment contract does not say your employer can do this, your employer may still be able to suspend you, but with pay. To show that it’s not a punishment the suspension will normally be on full pay.
chunks.plain_content:
Disciplinary procedures and action against you at work
Employment contracts
When a disciplinary issue is being looked into you might be suspended from work. This does not happen very often. If it does it should normally be with pay and you should be told why you’re being suspended.
You can be suspended without pay if your employment contract says your employer can do this, but they must be acting reasonably.
If your employment contract does not say your employer can do this, your employer may still be able to suspend you, but with pay. To show that it’s not a punishment the suspension will normally be on full pay.

heading_context: Disciplinary procedures and action against you at work
Employment rights when suspended
chunks.html_content: You keep your employment rights while suspended. If you do not get the right pay you may be able to make a claim to an employment tribunal for ‘unlawful deduction from wages’.
chunks.plain_content:
Disciplinary procedures and action against you at work
Employment rights when suspended
You keep your employment rights while suspended. If you do not get the right pay you may be able to make a claim to an employment tribunal for ‘unlawful deduction from wages’.

heading_context: Disciplinary procedures and action against you at work
Talking to other employees, customers and/or suppliers
chunks.html_content:
If you’re suspended, you might be told not to talk to other employees, customers and/or suppliers. If this means you cannot defend yourself properly at a disciplinary hearing, you could make an appeal.

But if you’ve been asked not to talk and you do, your employer might decide to take further disciplinary action against you.
chunks.plain_content:
Disciplinary procedures and action against you at work
Talking to other employees, customers and/or suppliers
If you’re suspended, you might be told not to talk to other employees, customers and/or suppliers. If this means you cannot defend yourself properly at a disciplinary hearing, you could make an appeal.
But if you’ve been asked not to talk and you do, your employer might decide to take further disciplinary action against you.

heading_context: Disciplinary procedures and action against you at work
Acas
chunks.html_content:
There are several organisations that could give you advice about disciplinary issues.

Acas (the Advisory, Conciliation and Arbitration Service) offers free, confidential and impartial advice about all employment rights issues.
chunks.plain_content:
Disciplinary procedures and action against you at work
Acas
There are several organisations that could give you advice about disciplinary issues.
Acas (the Advisory, Conciliation and Arbitration Service) offers free, confidential and impartial advice about all employment rights issues.
